What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

Stay curious and don‚Äôt be afraid to ask questions, no matter how simple they seem. SAP is a vast ecosystem, and nobody knows everything. Collaboration and continuous learning are key. Also, share your experiences! Whether it‚Äôs a small tip, a lesson learned, or a project success, your voice might be exactly what someone else needs to hear.

entry.title: Commitments in focus: How SAP S/4HANA is changing the management of financial commitments
entry.content:
What does commitment mean in the SAP context? 

Commitments describe the outstanding financial obligations of a company. These include, for example, orders, provisions or approved but not yet utilized funds. Although no payment has yet been made, these items impact liquidity, budgeting and risk assessment. 

SAP records such obligations in the system in several modules, in particular in Materials Management (MM), Financial Accounting (FI) and Controlling (CO). It is precisely at this interface that SAP S/4HANA‚Äôs decisive advantage emerges. 

GRAPHIC 1: Schematic overview of commitment processing between MM, FI and CO 

From static reporting to real-time insight 

SAP ECC already offered the option of managing commitments. However, the flow of information was often sluggish, fragmented and poorly integrated. Analyses were based on upstream reports that rarely reflected the current data situation. 

SAP S/4HANA solves this problem with real-time data processing. Every relevant transaction, be it an order, an investment application or a provision, is immediately recorded in the system and can be analyzed instantly. The underlying SAP HANA database ensures that data is not only quickly available but also intelligently linked. 

Comparison of COOI and ACDOCA: the evolution of commitment management 

A key difference between SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA lies in how financial obligations are managed and mapped. In SAP ECC, the COOI table (open orders, accruals and commitments) played a central role in commitment management. This table recorded open items and provided an overview of financial obligations but was often static and limited in terms of updates. 

With SAP S/4HANA, commitments are managed via the ACDOCA table. This central financial accounting table offers several advantages: 

  1. Real-time data processing:
    ACDOCA enables the recording and evaluation of transactions in real time. This means that every change is immediately reflected in the system, resulting in an up-to-date and accurate representation of financial obligations.      
  2. Integrated data structure:
    In contrast to the fragmented data management in ECC, ACDOCA integrates data from different modules and processes, providing a more comprehensive overview of financial obligations and their impact on the organization. 
  3. Extended analysis functions:
    With the ACDOCA data, organizations can perform complex analyses, such as plan/actual comparisons and trend analysis, which were previously difficult to carry out. This enables targeted management of the financial strategy and early identification of potential risks.     
  4. Flexibility and adaptability:
    ACDOCA's modern data structure supports easy adaptation to increasing requirements and the integration of new technologies such as AI-supported analyses and forecasts.     

This transition from COOI to ACDOCA clearly illustrates how SAP S/4HANA has advanced commitment management and supports companies in not only recording financial commitments, but also actively managing and strategically utilizing them. 

 GRAPHIC 2: Comparison of the commitment functionality in SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA 

 

Advantages of real-time data processing in SAP S/4HANA: 

  1. Application example - supply chain management:
    A company uses SAP S/4HANA to monitor its stock levels in real time. By recording orders and deliveries immediately, it can react more quickly to changes in demand and avoid bottlenecks. This leads to more efficient warehousing and reduced storage costs.
  2. Case study - Financial planning:
    A company in the energy sector implements SAP S/4HANA to gain real-time insight into its financial obligations. By immediately recording investment requests and provisions, the company can plan its liquidity more accurately and identify financial risks at an early stage. This leads to improved strategic decision-making and optimized budget management.     
  3.  

A new level of integration and analysis 

Another milestone is the seamless integration. SAP S/4HANA not only links MM, FI and CO technically, but also creates a unified view of obligations. This means that not only individual items, but also comprehensive budget evaluations or plan-versus-actual comparisons are possible at the touch of a button. 

At the same time, modern analytics functions offer new insights. Companies can recognize trends, identify anomalies at an early stage and make decisions based on reliable figures. 

Explanation of the Fiori interface and its advantages: 

The SAP Fiori interface offers a modern, intuitive and responsive design that greatly simplifies access to SAP applications. Users benefit from a role-based user experience that takes their specific tasks and needs into account. This enables a personalized and efficient way of working, as users can quickly access the information and functions relevant to their role without having to navigate through complex menus and transactions. The Fiori interface is particularly beneficial for users without in-depth technical system knowledge, as it facilitates the use of SAP applications and increases productivity through clear visualizations and simple interactions.  

GRAPHIC 3: SAP Fiori dashboard with current commitment values 

 

Exposure in the project business: actively managing cash flow 

Commitments have a particularly strategic impact in the project environment. SAP S/4HANA makes it possible to update payment obligations assigned to WBS elements, networks and orders, automatically and with precise value types. This creates the basis for project-related liquidity planning based on actual obligations. 

Down payments, allocations and project-related target/actual comparisons can also be clearly mapped. The ability to adjust financial items as required also increases flexibility. 

GRAPHIC 4: Project-oriented commitment process from the WBS element to the commitment 

Concrete implementation and specific functions of SAP S/4HANA 

User-friendliness thanks to the Fiori interface  

A key difference in the implementation of commitment management between SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA lies in the use of the modern Fiori interface, which enables more intuitive and user-friendly interaction. This interface supports a role-based and personalized user experience, allowing users to work efficiently without in-depth system knowledge. 

Use of intelligent functions for commitment management  

In addition, SAP S/4HANA offers specific functions such as AI-supported forecasting models that help to better manage future obligations and identify risks at an early stage. These models use historical data and probabilities to provide automated decision-making tools that significantly simplify commitment management. 

Technical implementation with CDS views and virtual data model 

In order to make optimum use of the functions and forecasting models mentioned, a robust database is required. The available CDS views in particular play a central role in analyzing the commitments. The content provides a manageable selection of CDS views that can be used to analyze the obligations. In the project context, it is advisable to check the associated virtual data model (VDM) and the definition of the key figures to see whether they reflect the requirements of the specialist area. This may result in expansion requirements that need to be mapped in the customer's own CDS views. In particular, when combining data from the two tables COOI and ACDOCA, it must be checked how these are merged. 

What's next? A look at the roadmap 

The development of SAP S/4HANA is far from complete. The upcoming releases promise, among other things, AI-supported forecasting models for commitment management. Automated decision-making aids based on historical data and probabilities will further reduce the burden on day-to-day business. 

A lot is also happening in terms of user-friendliness. The continuous improvement of the Fiori apps ensures that both controllers and project managers can work efficiently with commitments without in-depth system knowledge. 

Conclusion: Managing commitments, not just recording them 

Commitments not only show what a company has already incurred. They are a mirror of future expenditure and therefore an early warning system for the company's finances. SAP S/4HANA takes this tool to a new level by combining real-time data, integrated processes and dynamic analysis functions with modern implementation approaches and specific functions. With the Fiori interface and AI-supported forecasting models, commitments is transformed from a mere booking value into a strategic management tool. Companies that rely on these new possibilities can monitor commitments more specifically, manage budgets more precisely and identify financial risks earlier. The key to this lies in the intelligent use of existing data and a system that makes this data available in real time and in a user-friendly way. 

But that's just our view. How does your company perceive these changes? What experiences have you had with the implementation and use of SAP S/4HANA in commitment management? We look forward to hearing your perspectives and discussing new solutions together.

Âú®Êú¨Ê¨°Êõ¥Êñ∞‰∏≠ÔºåÊúÄÂºï‰∫∫Ê≥®ÁõÆÁöÑÊñ∞ÂäüËÉΩ‰πã‰∏ÄÊòØÈ°µÈù¢ËØÑËÆ∫ÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇËØ•ÂäüËÉΩÂÖÅËÆ∏Áî®Êà∑Â∞ÜËØÑËÆ∫ÈôÑÂä†Âà∞ÁâπÂÆöÊä•ÂëäÈ°µÈù¢ÔºåÂπ∂Â∞ÜÂÖ∂‰∏éÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Á≠õÈÄâÊù°‰ª∂„ÄÅÁª¥Â∫¶ÂíåÂ∫¶ÈáèËÅîÁ≥ªËµ∑Êù•„ÄÇËøô‰∏ç‰ªÖ‰øÉËøõ‰∫ÜÂÆûÊó∂Âçè‰ΩúÂíåÂèçÈ¶àË∑üË∏™ÔºåËøòÁ°Æ‰øùÂç≥‰ΩøËßÜÂõæÂèëÁîüÂèòÂåñÔºåÊØè‰∏™‰∫∫ÈÉΩÂú®Áõ∏ÂêåÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆËÉåÊôØ‰∏ãÂ∑•‰Ωú„ÄÇËøô‰∏ÄÊîπËøõÊòæËëóÊèêÂçá‰∫ÜÊï∞ÊçÆÂàÜÊûêÁöÑÊó†ÁºùÂçè‰ΩúËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇ

 

È°µÈù¢ËØÑËÆ∫ÂäüËÉΩÊ∂µÁõñ‰∫ÜÂá†‰∏™Áõ¥ËßÇÁöÑÊìç‰ΩúÔºö

  • Ê∑ªÂä†ËØÑËÆ∫Ôºö Áî®Êà∑ÂèØ‰ª•ËΩªÊùæ‰∏∫ÂΩìÂâçËßÜÂõæÊ∑ªÂä†ËØÑËÆ∫ÔºåÂπ∂Ëá™Âä®‰øùÂ≠òÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÂèòÈáè„ÄÅÁ≠õÈÄâÊù°‰ª∂„ÄÅÁª¥Â∫¶„ÄÅÁªìÊûÑÂíåÂ∫¶Èáè„ÄÇ

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Q3 2025 Release
entry.content:
SAP has officially rolled out its Q3 2025 release for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and it brings exciting new features that make working with data easier and faster.

  • Home Page Renewal: Personalized Productivity : The SAC home page has been completely redesigned to enhance user experience and productivity. New interface makes it easier than ever to navigate SAC and stay focused on what matters most. Key highlights include:
    • Customizable layout tailored to individual workflows
    • Quick access to: 
      • JustAsk (natural language query assistant)
      • Guided learning paths
      • Recent and featured files
      • Calendar highlights
  • AI-Assisted Features: AI deeply into SAC with several new capabilities:
    • Advanced Formula Generation -
      • Use natural language comments to generate complex formulas.
      • Automatically create descriptions for existing scripts.
      • Ideal for data actions and planning models.
    • AI-Assisted Commenting -
      • Summarize, translate, and rephrase comments in tables / story.
    • Chart Summary for PowerPoint -
      • Generate presentation-ready summaries of charts.
      • Save time and improve communication of insights.
    • Natural Language Calculations -
      • Define calculations in Data Analyzer using plain language.
  • Data Analyzer Enhancements: The Data Analyzer now supports:
    • Scheduling of reports
    • Color highlighting for better readability
    • Hyperlink integration into stories
    • New calculation options for deeper analysis
  • Better modeling Tools : Modeling in SAC is now more powerful and secure as -
    • New aggregation exception types for advanced logic
    • Conditional validation to ensure data quality
    • Data security-based display: restrict data visibility based on user roles.
  • Story building made easier:
    • New table builder experience with undo/redo
    • Arrow indicators to visually represent positive/negative values
    • Performance recommendations tab to optimize story performance.
  • System Administration Updates: 
    • SAP BTP cockpit integration for planning data storage.
    • Enhanced SSO (Single Sign-On) for easier access across SAP products

Reference : What's New in SAP Analytics Cloud | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: SAP EWM Podcast Episode 18 - Reporting & KPIs with SAP EWM
entry.content:
Welcome to our blog post for the SAP EWM Podcast Episode 18 - Reporting & KPIs with SAP EWM

You can listen to the podcast episode in English and in German on Spotify, Amazon Music, Apple Podcasts or Sway! Enjoy!

From Insight to Action... KPIs and Reporting in SAP EWM! 

In warehouse logistics, flexible and powerful reporting is essential to meet the diverse information needs of stakeholders‚Äîfrom warehouse managers and logistics leads to floor staff. SAP Extended Warehouse Management (SAP EWM) offers a rich set of tools and frameworks to support operational, tactical, and strategic reporting.
This blog post summarizes the key reporting capabilities in SAP EWM, including the Warehouse Management Monitor, Measurement Services, CDS views, and integration with SAP Analytics Cloud.

Continuous further development of operational reporting

 

1) Operational Reporting with the Warehouse Management Monitor

Since its first release in 2005, the Warehouse Management Monitor has been a central tool in SAP EWM for operational reporting. It enables real-time analysis and control of warehouse activities directly on the productive system.

Key features include:

  • Data Selection & Evaluation: Users can select and evaluate data for all EWM objects using filters, selection variants, and table layouts.
  • Monitor Methods: These allow direct actions such as printing documents, changing picking priorities, assigning resources, blocking stock, and more.
  • Automatic Refresh & Dashboards: Data views can be refreshed periodically, turning the monitor into a lightweight dashboard for workload visibility.
  • Snapshots: Manual or automated snapshots capture the state of warehouse data at specific points in time, useful for audits or historical comparisons.

SAP EWM Warehouse Monitor

 

Customizing the Warehouse Monitor for Personas and Roles

The monitor is not just a reporting tool‚Äîit‚Äôs a technical framework that supports extensive customization:

  • Role-Based Monitors: Customers can define monitors tailored to specific roles, showing only relevant nodes and methods.
  • Extensibility: New nodes and methods can be added via minor development and customizing, seamlessly integrated into the standard UI.
  • UI Adaptation with SAP Screen Personas: Field labels can be renamed to match user terminology (e.g., ‚ÄúHandling Unit‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúLoad Carrier ID‚Äù), improving usability and comprehension.

SAP EWM Monitor Adaption with SAP Screen Personas

 

2) EWM Measurement Services ‚Äì Defining Your Own KPIs

Introduced in 2007, EWM Measurement Services provide a structured approach to defining and calculating warehouse KPIs. The framework consists of three steps:

  1. Basic Measurement Services
    Predefined data selections that return raw KPIs (e.g., number of outbound delivery items).

  2. Tailored Measurement Services
    These apply selection criteria to basic services (e.g., delivery items posted as goods issue today), making KPIs more meaningful.

  3. Calculated Measurement Services
    Using a formula editor, tailored services can be combined and transformed into advanced KPIs (e.g., average delivery items per working hour).

Measurement Services in SAP EWM

 

These KPIs can be integrated into the SAP Fiori Launchpad as dynamic tiles using standard OData services. Thresholds can be defined, and if exceeded, SAP EWM can trigger alerts via the Alert Framework, enabling workflows, notifications, or emails.

How to Integrate EWM Measurement Services into SAP Fiori Launchpad:

  • SAP EWM key figure services can be called up via oData Service
  • This allows the key figures to be displayed as a KPI tile in the Fiori Launchpad, for example
  • The central oData service /SCWM/LM_MEASUREMENT_SERVICE_SRV is used for this.
  • This is called with the warehouse number, key figure service ID and key figure service type and returns the calculated KPI as a value.
  • See SAP Note 2070357 and the this SAP Community blog for additional information.

Measurement Service KPI in SAP Fiori Launchpad

 

Visualizing KPIs with EGF and Crystal Reports

SAP EWM also supports graphical visualization of KPIs:

  • The Easy Graphics Framework (EGF), available since 2007, allows visual representation of key figures.
  • In 2011, Crystal Reports were integrated into the Warehouse Monitor for enhanced graphical reporting

 

3) Embedded Analytics with CDS Views

The introduction of SAP HANA Live in 2014 marked the beginning of embedded analytics in SAP EWM. Although HANA Live was later replaced by Core Data Services (CDS), CDS views offer significant advantages:

  • Defined in the ABAP Dictionary and executed in SAP HANA, combining transportability with high performance.
  • Enable complex data selections and calculations directly in the database.
  • Used in standard apps like the Warehouse KPI App (introduced in 2017), which offers over 15 out-of-the-box KPIs.

SAP Core Data Services Views (CDS) - Simplified Illustration

 Find more information here: 

  • General Introduction to ABAP Core Data Services Gen
  • Overview of CDS Views for SAP EWM.

Users can also define their own KPIs using the ‚ÄúManage KPIs and Reports‚Äù app, leveraging standard or custom CDS views with selection criteria, thresholds, and drill-down options.

 

Embedded Analytics for SAP EWM based on CDS Views

 

This How-to-Guide helps you to build your own KPI or watch the following video: https://video.sap.com/media/t/1_92uy711w 

 

4) Beyond EWM ‚Äì Integration with SAP Analytics Cloud and Excel

CDS views extend reporting beyond SAP EWM:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): Enables real-time, cross-warehouse dashboards without data replication. EWM data can be combined with other sources for holistic insights.
  • Microsoft Excel Integration: With a small add-in, users can pull data directly from SAP EWM into Excel for further analysis‚Äîideal for organizations heavily reliant on Excel.

SAP EWM meets SAP Analytics Cloud

Find more information about SAP Analytics Cloud here: 
https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/cloud-analytics.html

CDS Views in MS Excel

 Find more information about CDS views in MS Excel for SAP EWM here: 
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESSOBJECTS_ANALYSIS_OFFICE

 

 

Strategic Reporting with SAP BW/4HANA

 

For long-term planning and strategic reporting, SAP recommends using SAP BW/4HANA:

  • EWM is an operational system; data such as deliveries, packaging, and serial numbers are transferred to systems like SAP ERP or SAP GBT after execution.
  • Documents should be archived after 3‚Äì6 months to maintain performance.
  • SAP BW/4HANA provides extractors and BI content for long-term reporting across time series.

Conclusion: Maximum Transparency in Logistics

SAP EWM, together with tools like SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP BW/4HANA, offers a comprehensive reporting landscape‚Äîfrom simple KPIs with alerting to advanced dashboards and predictive analytics. These capabilities empower warehouse operations with actionable insights and support data-driven decision-making

Further Resources

  • üéßSAP EWM Podcast Episode 11 ‚Äì Flexibility and Modularity
  • üìπKPI creation demo video (linked in podcast notes)
  • üìÑSAP EWM Product Documentation ‚Äì Chapter: Analytics

Please visit our SAP EWM Podcast Landing Page with all Episodes, Blog Posts and Podcast Notes!

entry.title: Fixing the ‚ÄúMore Members Available‚Äù Issue in SAP Analysis for Office based on Custom CDS Views
entry.content:
While working with SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics and SAP Analysis for Office (AFO), you may encounter the message: "More Members Available"

This typically appears when filtering or selecting values in prompts, and it indicates that the number of available members exceeds the display threshold. Although SAP provides a configuration setting (FetchMemberLimit) to increase the limit, this doesn‚Äôt always resolve the issue, especially when the value help includes duplicate entries.

Standard Fix: You can try increasing the member limit in AFO:

Go to File > Analysis > Customize Analysis > Technical Configuration
Set FetchMemberLimit to a value higher than the expected number of members.

However, this only works if the number of members is within the new threshold. If duplicate entries exist, the system still struggles to display all entries. In many cases, the issue arises from repeated members in the value help CDS view. This is common when the value help is generated from a custom CDS view without ensuring uniqueness.

To resolve this, modify your value help CDS view to return distinct values.

Syntax

define view XXXXX as select distinct from XXXX
{

}

In previous blogs, we have seen how value help can be generated with help of below annotations.

@Consumption.filter.multipleSelections: true
@Consumption.valueHelp:


Conclusion
The ‚ÄúMore Members Available‚Äù issue in SAP Analysis for Office can be frustrating, but it‚Äôs often solvable with a simple tweak to your CDS view design. By ensuring your value help view returns distinct values, you can improve usability and performance in your embedded analytics reports.

entry.title: Exploring CDS based Analytical Models with the Relation Explorer - analytical view/perspective
entry.content:
Relation explorer analytical view / analytical perspective makes it easy to get an overview of the analytical model with very less clicks. No need to open all the views to understands details.

We start small , looking to a branch of a star schema , dimension Connection ( /DMO/ANA_I_Connection ) which is part of the flight data model.  After calling the relation explorer we see the Relation Explorer Tab in the below section of the screenshot.

Relation Explorer tab shows:

  • in the left pane the associations from the dimension to other CDS views over all levels are visualizes . It starts fully expanded!
    next to the CDS view name we see the view type. E.g. /DMO/ANA_I_CARRIER is of type [Dimension]
  • in the right pane one can see all the elements of current view. As /DMO/ANA_I_Connection is selected all elements of this dimension are displayed.
    • One can select (single click) any other view e.g. /DMO/ANA_I_CARRIER and the right pane get updated with the elements of that view.
    • double clicking the view will directly open the view 
  • the right pane displays all elements grouped by roles.
    • In this example we have 2 keys and e.g. expanding AirlineID show label and additional details about association and InfoObject. In case of compounded parent we would have seen the Parent element.
    • double clicking AirlineID highlight the element in the source ( see line 21 )
    • [Text] gives a hint that AirlineID has text, this is missing for ConnetionID -> no Text supported
    • Attributes list all dimension attributes. Last one, DistanceUnit is a Unit element.
    • the Unit group show all unit related elements.
    • other group are shown if relevant.

One can also start the analytical Relation Explorer based on query or cube view.
In both cases the cube view is opened and visualizes the cube with all associations .

We change focus and look to the example of a query - starting relation explorer shows the cube definition including dimension Connection from above.

with one view

  • in the left pane we get all associations visualizes. View names are shown with the view types
  • in the right pane we can see all 13 dimensions of the cube and get if dimension support Text, have Attributes or Hierarchies
    • from 1st screenshot we already know that Text, Attributes and Hierarchies are available for AirlineID
    • expanding ConnectionID show that it is compounded to AirlineID
  • we see all 5 measures with additional details like aggregation method and unit
  • with " Units (2) " we see the unit related dimensions. This section only list those dimension that are unit relevant.  Expanding the dimension like CurrencyCode lists all related measures. 
    ( Both dimension are also listed in dimension section. )
  • for time based dimension one can directly understand the base dimension and wherefrom it is derived without looking into the source ( see below snippet with FiscalYearMonth )

 

How to start the Relation Explorer

call relation explorer to see the view

right click somewhere in the CDS view 

( in case of CDS view type cube, dimension or query the analytical view is the default view )

  • If the view is not shown, choose Configure Context and activate it.
  • one can switch any time to different perspective / context if needed

 

 

 

Release Info:  analytical view / analytical perspective started with

  • BW/4HANA 2023 FP 04 
  • S/4HANA Public Cloud and Privat Cloud OP2023

entry.title: Reporting and Analytics
entry.content:
Co-Author: Gergana Deneva; in addition, generative AI was used to help create this content

Elevate Your SAP S/4HANA Experience: We Value Your Feedback!

At SAP,  we're committed to enhancing the reporting and analytics capabilities of SAP S/4HANA to better meet your evolving needs. We are therefore excited to invite you to participate in a customer engagement initiative focused on ‚ÄúReview Booklets and MDA: the next level of SAP S/4HANA Reporting and Analytics.‚Äù

Why Your Input Matters

Your insights and experiences are invaluable to us. By sharing your requirements and feedback, you help shape the future of SAP S/4HANA, ensuring that our solutions are tailored to your specific needs. This interactive initiative is applicable for both Public Cloud and Private Cloud Edition users.

What's in it for you?

This customer engagement initiative aims to delve into the next level of SAP S/4HANA Reporting and Analytics. You will have the opportunity to provide feedback and learn more about the following topics:

  • Review Booklets: Explore the latest innovations in report generation and customization.
  • Multidimensional Data Data Analytics (MDA): Discover advanced analytics capabilities designed to provide deeper insights into your business operations.

Your feedback will help us refine the apps, ensuring they align with the requirements of your business.

How to Participate

We‚Äôve made it easy for you to get involved:

  1. Visit the Influence Page: Go to the campaign page on SAP Influence.
  2. Register: Click on the registration link and follow the simple steps to sign up. Please note that the registration period is open until November 15th.
  3. Provide Feedback: Once registered, you will have access to the platform where you can share your thoughts and requirements.

How you'll benefit

Participating in this initiative brings several advantages:

  • Direct Influence: Your feedback will have a direct impact on the product roadmap.
  • Early Access: Gain early insights into upcoming features and innovations.
  • Community Engagement: Network with other SAP S/4HANA users and share best practices.

Don't Miss Out!

This is your chance to play a pivotal role in the evolution of SAP S/4HANA Reporting and Analytics. Your valuable contributions will help us create a more robust and user-friendly platform that meets the diverse needs of our community.

We look forward to your feedback and are excited to collaborate with you on this journey - register now!

Important Dates: Registration Deadline: November 15th

For more information and to sign up, please visit the campaign page.

Thank you for your continued support and partnership. Together, we can drive innovation and create exceptional business solutions.

entry.title: How to derive dynamic text label in CDS view with value lookup
entry.content:
Background:

Recently I got a requirement to create an account payable aging report which contains dynamic text based on user input, for example, user input aging interval as: 30, 60, 90. in the output of the report, the required report format will be:

CustomerDue in 30 daysDue in 31-60 daysDue in 61-90 daysDue 91+ days
1001$300$600$900$1200

In the traditional SAP BW world, this can be easily achieved by Text variable, however in SAP CDS view, dynamic text is not available in early versions. In my current system version, the version is ABAP 7.58, and it supports this annotation very well.

Solution:

So instead of going this complex scenario, I will use a simple SAP data source:  SFLIGHT to achieve the similar requirement.

Scenario explanation:

There will be only one base measure called Airfare, based on the user input: number of Days X, the output will show the AirFare, X Days AirFare, X+1 Days AirFare, the highlighted two columns text will be dynamically derived based on the user input

Year MonthAirFare10 Days AirFare11 Days AirFare
02.2023$300$600$900

This is how the end to end implementation work look like

  • Define a helper view: this is to return the day + 1

  • Define cube level data model, with base fare, base fare * input days, base fare * input days + 1, the measure if purely for distingush the different dollar value

  • Comes with the fun part, in the query view, we define the parameter which populate the derived dayPlus1 using lookup view which defined in first step:

  • In the measure column, wewill appy the dynamic text using annotation: @Consumption.dynamicLabel:

Now Let's run the CDS view from BW query, as you can see user will be prompt to fill input days (default value is 10):

The measure column will derive the text dynamically based on user input and helper view:

 

With the help to combine annotation @Consumption.dynamicLabel and @Consumption.derivation.lookupEntity, we will be able to achieve the same requirement in the BW world by using Text variable and custom exit. 

I hope this blog give you some help with the how dynamic text can be implemented using SAP CDS view, if you have any questions, please feel free to leave a message.

entry.title: CDS : How to define default Key Display in Analytical queries
entry.content:
This blog explains how to define default key display settings in analytical queries, ensuring user-friendly key visualization. Many Hierarchy Nodes and Dimensions have compounded keys that are shown as a long-concatenated keys during runtime. Sometimes its not needed to see the concatenated long key. To enhance readability, @AnalyticsDetails.query.keyDisplay annotation is use to specify the default display behaviour for key.

Annotation: @AnalyticsDetails.query.keyDisplay

Accepted Values:

  • #NOT_COMPOUND: Displays the key as a non-compounded characteristic value.
  • #COMPOUND: Displays the key as a compounded characteristic value (concatenated long key).
  • #CONTEXT_DEPENDENT: Displays the key based on its uniqueness. If the compounded key is unique due to drill-down selection, it will be shown as non-compounded

Example

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_ALLOWED
@EndUserText.label: 'Query: Simple Example for Key display'
define transient view entity ZLR_PC_KEY_DISP 
provider contract analytical_query
as projection on ZOQ_FLIGHT {

  
  @AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #ROWS
  carrid,
  
  @AnalyticsDetails.query: {
      axis: #ROWS,
    totals: #SHOW
  }
  @EndUserText.label: 'ConnectionID Not Compound'
  @AnalyticsDetails.query.keyDisplay: #NOT_COMPOUND
  connid,
  
  @AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #FREE
  @analytics.hidden: true
  currency,
   
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'currency'
  @EndUserText.label: 'Booking total 2019'
  paymentsum

 
}
where flyear =  '2019'
  and currency = 'EUR'

Output

Release Info

This feature is available from Cloud release 2508

SAP Note: 3600690 - CDS: query display key settings

entry.title: Simple understanding of Hierarchies in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics‚Äì Part 1 (Basics)
entry.content:
Accurate CDS hierarchy modeling and understanding is critical for financial reporting and operational analytics. Without well-defined hierarchies, drill-down analysis and aggregated insights become challenging. This blog demystifies hierarchy concepts in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics and shows how they power SAC,Multidimensiona Reports , AFO and Datasphere scenarios.This blog will give you the basic understanding of Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana)

What This Blog Covers

  • Common hierarchy terminologies
  • Types of hierarchies in CDS Views
  • Standard hierarchies in S/4HANA
  • Why custom hierarchies matter


1. Key Terminologies-

Before diving into implementation, let‚Äôs clarify the basics:

  • Root Node : Top-most node in the hierarchy. Has No parent. Signifies the Hierarchy Structure and contains the Hierarchy metadata. A hierarchy can have several root nodes.
  • Hierarchy Node : Represents a group or element in the hierarchy.
  • Parent Node : A node that has child nodes beneath it.
  • Child Node : Belongs to a parent node.
  • Leaf Node : Lowest node in the hierarchy (end point).
  • Hierarchy Directory : Stores hierarchy definitions.
  • Siblings : Nodes sharing the same parent.
  • Hierarchy Level : Indicates depth of a node in the hierarchy. Levels can be defined as 0,1,2,3 . In S/4 EA change level based hierarchies to Parent child hierarchies .
  • Recursive Hierarchy: Nodes can reference themselves (e.g., Org Structure). Implemented using self-association in CDS.
  • Hierarchy Node Texts: These contain the descriptive names or labels associated with the hierarchy nodes, typically derived from the related master data (for example, the name or description of a General Ledger account or Product Hierarchy Description).
  • Orphan nodes, These are the nodes missing a link to a root. You can choose to ignore them, raise an error, or promote them as alternative roots using annotations like ORPHANS = ROOT

2. Example of a Hierarchy-

Company ‚Üí Product Category ‚Üí Product ‚Üí Variant Shoe Model 1

Example:

  • Company (ABC Corp)  ‚Üí Root Node -> The top most node in hierarchy (Defined via Hierarchy Directory and Root node has no parent defined)---- To be discussed in details in another Part 2.
  • Product Category (Footwear)  ‚Üí Child of Company->A Parent Node for Product but this is not the Root node(Since it has Company as a Parent Node).
  • Product (Shoes)  ‚Üí Child of Product Category->Parent Node for Variant
  • Variant (Shoe Model 1)  ‚Üí Leaf Node->Lowest Node in the hierarchy

 In SAP: For Cost Center or Profit Center hierarchy, Controlling Area could be the root node.

3. Types of Hierarchies in CDS Views-

In S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, hierarchies are modeled using CDS annotations. Most common type:

  • Parent-Child Hierarchy üîó Always recursive. Each node references its parent, forming a tree structure. Example: Cost Center hierarchy where each cost center belongs to a higher-level.

 

  • Level-Based Hierarchy üîóNot supported in S4 Hana Embedded analytics as Analytical engine supports only Parent Child Hierarchy for drill downs and aggregations.

CDS Annotation Example:

@Hierarchy.parentChild:
{ recurse:          {   parent: 'ParentNode',   child:  'HierarchyNode'   },
  siblingsOrder:    {   by: 'SequenceNumber',    direction: 'ASC'   },
  directory:        '_Hierarchy' }

4. Standard Hierarchies in S/4HANA-

SAP delivers several predefined hierarchies:

  • Cost Center Hierarchy ‚Äì For controlling and cost reporting
  • Profit Center Hierarchy ‚Äì For profitability analysis
  • GL Account Hierarchy ‚Äì For financial statements
  • Product Hierarchy ‚Äì For material classification
  • EHS Location Hierarchies ‚Äì For Environment, Health & Safety compliance

5. Custom Hierarchies-

Business requirements often demand custom hierarchies:

  • Example: A sales region hierarchy combining geography and product lines.
  • Implemented using CDS Views by developing a relation between Dimension Views and Hierarchy View.

6. Why Hierarchies Matter?

  • Enable drill-down reporting in SAC or Fiori Multidimensional Reports/AFO.
  • Support aggregations at multiple levels
  • Provide flexibility for planning and analytics

7. Technical Details: Where Hierarchies Are Stored-

  • HRRP_NODE_N Table: Stores Parent Node info, hierarchy node level details, and relationships between nodes(Example where GL Account/Profit Center/Cost Center Hierarchy details are stored).
  • HRRP_DIR_N Table: Stores Hierarchy Directory info (name, version, metadata).

üëâWhen you activate or create a hierarchy (standard or custom), these tables are updated.

  • HRRP_NODE_N = Node-level details (Parent-Child relationships)
  • HRRP_DIR_N = Directory-level details (Hierarchy header info)

8. Hierarchy Components & Annotations-

  • A well-defined hierarchy in CDS has multiple views:

Source(Master Data) View: Provides key fields and relationships (Eg GL Account/Cost Center/Product related details).
Hierarchy View: Contains the relationships and parent‚Äìchild links. Eg - Hierarchy(Child) Node, Parent Node, Node levels etc.
Directory View: Provides metadata about hierarchy variants -- Optional.
Text Views for labeling nodes and directory entries . Eg: GL account and it's text/ Cost center and it's text etc.

Proper annotations (@Hierarchy.parentChild, @ObjectModel.dataCategory: #HIERARCHY) control recursion, sibling order, orphan handling, and directory association

Notes:

  • Parent‚ÄìChild Hierarchy: Supported in CDS for analytics; recursive structure.
  • Level-Based Hierarchy: Not supported in CDS for analytical consumption (only parent‚Äìchild works for drill-down).
  • Orphan nodes = Nodes without a parent.
  • A Parent Node can have multiple Hierarchy Nodes/Child nodes but a hierarchy node cannot have multiple parents
  • A node can appear under different parents in different hierarchy versions, not in the same hierarchy( It usually refers to alternate hierarchy versions or variants, not simultaneous parents in the same hierarchy. For example:

Hierarchy Variant/Version 1: Region ‚Üí Country ‚Üí City

Hierarchy Variant/Version 2: Sales Channel ‚Üí Country ‚Üí City.This is managed via Hierarchy Directory.

  • A CDS hierarchy cannot serve as the underlying source for building another CDS hierarchy.

Next Article (Part 2)

  • How to activate Standard hierarchies and develop Custom Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana EA).
  • How to consume hierarchies in SAC
